instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
Hi,
I've got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board here that won't turn on. Magsafe light is on, but nothing else happens. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 8.56 volts but isn't stable. Replaced <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, didn't help.
Any suggestions where to look next?
Thanks, Rick

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
Resistance <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>:
* 17/18: 3 ohms
* 27/28: 20 ohms

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: Varies slightly between 16.65 and 16.66v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="rvanpruissen, post: 19812"]Resistance <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>:
* 17/18: 3 ohms
* 27/28: 20 ohms

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: Varies slightly between 16.65 and 16.66v[/QUOTE]

That's only 10mV... Negligible.
You got 3V42?
S5 rails?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message: Thanks. I think all S5 rails are fluctuating because of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. None of them are 0V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message: Does the machine power from a charged battery? <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> ok?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> measures fine. Tried the machine with it's own battery (status unknown) and this seems to stabilise <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.67V. I'll try and find a properly charged battery next. Any suggestions as to what this means and what my next step would be? Kind of lost on this one.
Thanks, Rick

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
Nope, know good battery doesn't change a thing compared to above. So info so far:

* <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 8.56 volts but isn't stable (stabilises at 8.67V with battery attached)
* Resistance <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> (replaced):
   - 17/18: 3 ohms
   - 27/28: 20 ohms
* <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: Varies slightly between 16.65 and 16.66v (stabilised when ISL was removed)
* No S5 rails present, they are fluctuating because of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. None of them are 0V.

Any suggestions?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unstable/pulsing
threads.message:
Never mind, I just fixed this one. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> was shorted on <CAPACITOR>C7553</CAPACITOR>. Repealed and replaced it and now it's working again. Thanks for your suggestions people.
Cheers, Rick
